reviewText: This DVD of the New Year Eve Concert of the Berlin Philharmonic under guest conductor Gustavo Dudamel is a first rate entertainment.The repertoire showcases Dudamel's musicality and the pieces suit his temperament to a "T".The beautiful mezzo-soprano Elina Garanca sings here French arias by Saint-Saens, Berlioz and Bizet, and other 'Latinate' songs like Granada. These songs by Chapi and Lara do not necessarily suit her rather icy musical temperament, but in this case, with the partnership of the BPO under Dudamel, it works well.There is a balance that is well struck between the conductor, the orchestra and the singer. The BPO plays opulently, with star soloists and concert master sharing, if not stealing, a good many parts of the show. The camera is also more than ready to catch those moments, though the wonderful concert master could still be better showcased in such a starry setup.In a diamond set up as such, it is well-nigh impossible for any one performer to 'steal the show'. And such does not happen. Rather, we are in for a wonderful collaboration between the orchestra, conductor and soloist. Everything put together in utmost coherence, and that tells alot about the indiviuals' musical calibre. If there is any complaint, it is that there was no vocal piece from Falla.Other than that minor quibble, this is thoroughly enjoyable.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Dresden Staatskapelle is beautiful.  The sound was excellent, the video clear.  To listen to Renee Fleming is always a treat.  I thought the video director was a bit frenetic.  During the scene with the ballet dancers he kept switching from the dancers to the orchestra breaking the flow and logic of the dance.  Except for that it was a fine production.  I watched it twice -- an example of how much I enjoyed it.
summary: A beautiful concert, wish I had been there
Title: N/A

reviewText: It doesn't get better than this. Gorgeous house, wonderful orchestra, chorus dressed to kill, conductor leading with perfect tempi, perfect video and sound. Of course Fleming is terrific, she always is; but so are all the other singers. One regrets not being there, but this next best thing is to be grateful for. Cannot recommend too hightly. Ausgezeichnet! Wunderbar!!

reviewText: Prequel: I have been informed that Amazon have wrongly listed this review under the Dudamel Elina Garanca New Year's concert DVD. This is beyond my control so please be patient. It is also listed correctly under the 2010 New Year's Eve Concert at Dresden so please ignore it if you are looking for the Dudamel and carry on reading if you are interested in the 2010 New Year's Eve Concert at Dresden. Thanks, Ian Giles..................................................This is the first of a projected series of New Year's Eve concerts from Dresden. It differs from the Berlin concerts held at the same time in so far as the Berlin concerts are generally orchestra-based concerts which occasionally have featured vocal sections. This concert is, in effect, an abbreviated concert performance of one work - The Merry Widow by Lehar so there is a great deal of focus on the chosen soloists and plenty for the choir as well. There are also a few appropriate purely orchestral items, one of which enables the insertion of ballet dancers in much the same way as in the Vienna New Year's Day concerts.The singers are all of star quality and clearly thoroughly enjoy the occasion and this enthusiasm communicates well. Renée Fleming, looking radiantly happy and undoubtedly very attractive, could well be many men's dream of a Merry Widow outside of the world of operetta of course! Christopher Maltman makes a good partner for her and both make a believable pair, acting their parts as well as a concert performance will allow. Carolina Ullrich and Andej Dunaev also enter fully into the spirit of the occasion as do the other featured solo singers.Thielemann directs his fine orchestra with complete concentration, drawing upon his early years of experience when he regularly conducted operetta. The choir is excellent. The concert concludes with J. Strauss II's little known final waltz, An der Elbe and the enthusiastic audience will no doubt be looking forward to more New Year's Eve concerts from Dresden as already planned.The imaging is crisp giving a mixture of detailed and general views. The sound is presented in DTS 5.0 and stereo. It seems a shame that at present there is not a Blu-ray version available. Apart from that comment, which does not affect this particular DVD issue, it seems obvious that this release is of 5 star quality throughout and should give a great deal of pleasure to purchasers.I would suggest that this disc is deserving of serious consideration by anyone interested in an abbreviated version of the Merry Widow in concert form, or of discs featuring Renee Fleming or by anyone interested in the particular occasion.............................................Some dialogue from the comments section that may offer further help:It is indeed a shame that there is no Blu-ray (yet). I'll also reiterate a comment I have made about a couple of other releases: the omission of a subwoofer channel can be a serious flaw for listeners with a home-theater setup in which typically the subwoofer handles the majority of the bass ("subwoofer" is a misnomer in such cases--it handles all the bass frequencies that satellite speakers cannot). It's not a problem for those with full-range front left and right speakers, nor for those who have A/V receivers that can synthesize a substitute bass channel. This is a very odd way to configure a soundtrack; fortunately, I have a workaround, but it requires modifying my usual setup. I had previously associated this quirk only with Unitel releases (some of which are licensed to DG), but this DVD appears to be of EuroArts origin; I sincerely hope that this practice is not spreading.  (U.S. review)............................................
summary: A most enjoyable New Year's Eve concert

reviewText: For the benefit of those who are not so familar with these two incredible artists, both of them are currently considered to be the BEST in their business. Elina stays in Europe, while Gustavo Dudamel is now leading the L.A. Philharmonic. Your purchasing of this DVD should be one of your best bet.I had this DVD in late January. DGG did not released it to the US but to other countries first.Elina Garanca is considered to be the BEST mezzo-soparno at the moment, and MHO is she deserved the title, and the "Dude" simply makes magic.I have about seven other versions of Saint-saen's Samson et Delila because I love that music. Comparing with other singers, no one can sing nearly as good as Elina. Meanwhile, Gustavo Dudamel is one of the most sensitive conductor ever. Super precise, but would never rob nor compete with the singer's voice. Whenever Elina sings, Dudamel would immediately lower the sound level of the orchestra so that she doesn't have to fight with the orchestra.  Elina's voice and pitch and timing and everything else is superbly perfect.Her Bizet's Carmen shows how involved and how deeply her understanding of the music is. The Carmen makes me smile, and on top, she was also teasing Dudemal, which the music is supposed to be. However, when she sings Saint-Saen's Samson et Delila, the mood is completely different. She bring tears to my eyes. It is very, very touching and because of this great performance, I went through a lot of effort just to get the DVD before it was release here in the U.S., and now I am a happy camper and have also almost worn out the DVD.You can now just double click on Amazon.com and you can get this incredible DVD in two days.  Not very fair #to me !!# but it is worth it  :-))Enjoy !

reviewText: Dudamel conducts the Berlin Philharmonic for a 2010 New Year's Eve Concert with Elina Garanca (mezzo soprano) and an opera pal of Anna Netrebko. If they are not from Venezuela, they must be from behind the iron curtain (in this case Latvia). The orchestra plays Berlioz, Saint-Saens, Bizet and for Gustavo: De Falla.
summary: Look Up In The Sky: It's A Bird, It's A Plane. No It's Superman  (aka Gustavo Dudamel)
